stem: The nurse in an outpatient clinic is reviewing laboratory results and assessment notes for four clients on Lithium therapy. Based on the documentation in the Lithium Level & Side Effects Log, match each level/symptom set to the correct clinical status.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient A: Routine check. Reports mild fine hand tremors when drinking coffee. 
Patient B: Reports severe diarrhea and 'stomach flu' over the weekend. Now feeling persistently dizzy and confused. 
Patient C: New onset of vomiting, blurred vision, and a coarse tremor. Reports severe muscle weakness.

tabs.title: Lithium Level & Side Effects Log
tabs.content:
PatientLithium LevelSymptom ClusterStatus
A0.9 mEq/LMild fine hand tremors; PolyuriaTherapeutic
B1.8 mEq/LBlurred vision; Slurred speech; ConfusionModerate Toxicity
C2.6 mEq/LSeizures; Oliguria; Cardiovascular CollapseSevere Toxicity

rows.text: Level 0.6–1.2 mEq/L with mild fine tremors and polyuria
Level 1.5–2.0 mEq/L with blurred vision, ataxia, and nausea/diarrhea
Level > 2.5 mEq/L with seizures, coma, and multi-organ failure

columns.text: Toxic Range / Hold medication and notify provider

rationale.correct: The therapeutic range for Lithium (c1) is 0.6–1.2 mEq/L (r1). Levels above 1.5 are considered toxic (c2), with symptoms like blurred vision and ataxia (r2). Levels above 2.5 are severe emergencies (r3). Hyponatremia and dehydration (r4) are major risk factors for toxicity (c3) because the kidneys retain lithium when sodium is low.
clinicalPearls: Lithium is a SALT. If sodium is low, lithium goes high.
Fine tremors are expected; COARSE tremors indicate toxicity.
Patients must maintain a STEADY intake of salt and water; do not restrict or over-consume.

questionTrap.trap: Telling a lithium patient to go on a 'low-sodium diet' to prevent hypertension.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: NEVER reduce sodium for a lithium patient unless you want them to become toxically high on lithium.

mnemonic.title: Lithium Level
mnemonic.expansion: L-Long-term (Bipolar). I-Inverse to Sodium (Low Na = High Li). T-Therapeutic (0.6-1.2). H-Heavy Metal toxicity.
